Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 46162  
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2012 
 
 
Strengthening Disaster and Climate Risk Resilience 
in Urban Development in the Pacific  
(Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  PacRIS  –  Pacific Risk Information System 
  PCRAFI  –  Pacific Catastrophe Risk Assessment and Financing Initiative 
  SPC  –  Secretariat of the Pacific Community

GLOSSARY 
 
  resilience  –  The ability of a system, community, or society exposed to hazards to resist, 
absorb, accommodate to, and recover from the effects of a hazard in a timely 
and efficient manner, including through the preservation and restoration of its 
essential basic structures and functions. 
  risk  –  The combination of a hazardous event occurring and the impact or 
consequence of that event. 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  X. Yao, Pacific Department (PARD) 
Director  I. Matsumoto, Urban, Social Development and Public Management

Team leader  A. Woodruff, Urban Development Specialist, PARD  
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the  2011 regional  Pacific  Platform for Disaster  Risk  Management meetings, 
Pacific  developing  member  country  (DMC)  governments  stressed  the  importance  of  (i) 
effectively preventing and risk proofing development investments and (ii) strengthening disaster 
risk management and related human resource capacities. Pacific DMCs also called for further 
support to better integrate disaster and climate risk information into development planning. The 
technical assistance (TA) aims to respond to this request by assisting Fiji, Papua New Guinea, 
Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, and Vanuatu, to build their capacity in mainstreaming climate 
change and natural disaster risks into urban and infrastructure planning using available data 
and risk models. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Pacific DMCs, as small island developing states, are vulnerable to economic shocks, 
natural  hazards,  and  climate  change,  which  pose  a  significant  challenge  to  sustainable 
development and progress toward achieving the Millennium Development Goals. Pacific DMCs 
are highly exposed to the adverse effects of climate change and natural hazards, including 
floods, droughts, tropical cyclones, earthquakes, and tsunamis, and have a low capacity to 
manage the resulting risks. Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity 
of  extreme  weather  events  and  to  introduce  new  hazards  such  as  sea  level  rise  and 
temperature  changes.  The  2009  tsunami  that  hit  Samoa  caused  high  human  losses  and 
extensive damage to the country’s infrastructure. The cost of recovery was estimated at 22% of 
Samoa’s gross domestic product over a 3–4 year period.2 In April 2012, Fiji was affected by 
severe flooding, resulting in damages equivalent to around 1.5% of the country’s gross domestic 
product.3 
 
3.  At the same time, poorly planned urban development is increasing the exposure of 
Pacific DMCs to natural hazard and climate change-related events. The large concentration of 
people, infrastructure, enterprises, and public institutions within cities and towns makes urban 
areas more vulnerable to these events compared with rural areas. Urban centers in the region 
are also predominantly situated in hazard-prone locations such as in low-lying coastal areas that 
are exposed to flooding, sea level rise, and storm surge. Pacific DMCs are rapidly urbanizing: 
Fiji,  Papua  New  Guinea,  Samoa,  Solomon  Islands, Tonga,  and  Vanuatu  have  among the 
highest urban growth rates in the Pacific region. As the region’s urban centers expand, there is 
growing  unplanned  encroachment  into  higher  risk  areas,  such  as  exposed  shorelines  or 
locations that are prone to flooding. 
   
4.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB), the Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC),4 
and the World Bank jointly launched the Pacific Catastrophe Risk Assessment and Financing 
Initiative  (PCRAFI)  in  2007  to  increase  the financial  resilience  of  Pacific  DMCs  to  natural 
disasters and to enable them to better cope with the aftermath of such events.5 The PCRAFI 
aims to (i) develop a regional catastrophe risk insurance pool to enhance the capacity of Pacific

DMCs to manage natural disasters, (ii) provide immediate liquidity resources to restore essential 
services  to  countries  affected  by  natural  disasters,  and  (iii)  assist  with  recovery  and 
reconstruction activities. The World Bank launched a subregional catastrophe insurance pilot 
scheme involving the Marshall Islands, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, and Vanuatu in 2012. 
 
5.  ADB’s contribution to the development of the regional catastrophe insurance scheme 
under the PCRAFI included identifying and recording country-specific geographic information 
system datasets of buildings, major infrastructure, major crops, and population. About 80,000 
buildings and major infrastructure were physically inspected, and about 3 million buildings and 
other assets, mostly in rural areas, were inferred from satellite imagery. The PCRAFI also 
developed the region’s most comprehensive regional historical hazard catalog and historical 
loss database for major disasters, as well as country-specific hazard models that simulate 
earthquakes and tropical cyclones. The PCRAFI’s outputs also include risk maps showing the 
geographic distribution of potential losses for each Pacific DMC as well as other visualization 
products of the risk assessments. This information is stored in the Pacific Risk Information 
System (PacRIS) housed at the SPC and can be accessed through an open-source web-based 
platform. 
 
6.  During the development of the PacRIS, it became apparent that this data has significant 
value  for  other  applications  beyond  disaster  risk  financing.  A  lack  of  climate  and  hazard 
exposure  information  has  constrained  progress  in  mainstreaming  climate  and  disaster  risk 
considerations  into  urban  and  infrastructure  development  planning,  which  is  critical  for 
safeguarding social and economic development gains in the region. As a result, Pacific DMCs 
have  tended  to  respond  to  the  symptoms  of  natural  disaster  events  through  relief  and 
reconstruction efforts, rather than dealing with the root causes through better development 
planning. The PacRIS contains information on (i) the probability of hazard events occurring in a 
particular location, (ii) the value and ownership of assets threatened by natural disasters and 
climate change, and (iii) information about the likely impacts of such events, which is critical for 
disaster and climate resilient development planning. 
 
7.  Catastrophe risk insurance outreach activities carried out to date as part of the PCRAFI 
have primarily targeted Pacific DMC treasury and finance officials. As a result, there is limited 
awareness of PacRIS data and its value as a planning and risk-screening tool among other 
national and municipal government agencies that are responsible for urban and sector planning 
as well as among development partners that support infrastructure investment activities in the 
region. Pacific DMC officials also have limited capacity to analyze natural hazard and climate 
change information and apply it to development planning. Awareness and capacity building 
activities are therefore needed to enable Pacific DMCs and development partners to use this 
data to develop climate and disaster resilient policies, plans, programs, and projects. 
 
8.  There  is  increasing  recognition  that  disaster  risk  reduction  and  climate  change 
adaptation share a common focus in reducing the vulnerability of communities and contributing 
to sustainable development. Many governments are recognizing the important role that disaster 
risk  reduction  plays  in  reducing  the  adverse  impacts  of  climate  change.  This  includes 
acknowledging that reducing risks related to current weather and climate conditions is usually 
the best way to prepare for addressing risks related to climate change. Systematic consideration 
and integration of disaster and climate risks as part of planning processes ensure the viability of 
investments to support the achievement of social and economic development objectives and 
ensure that planned development activities do not increase the vulnerability of people and 
assets to such risks.

3 
9.  An effective integrated disaster risk management framework to protect development 
gains in Pacific DMCs combines ex ante investments in disaster risk reduction and climate 
change adaptation with ex post disaster risk financing instruments to cope with residual risks 
following  a  natural  disaster  event.  Moving forward,  the  PCRAFI  will  support  an  integrated 
approach to managing natural disasters in the region by reducing vulnerability to climate change 
and natural disaster risks through better development planning, and by supporting post-disaster 
recovery through the proposed regional catastrophe insurance facility. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be that social and economic development in Pacific DMCs is resilient to 
climate change and natural hazard events. The outcome will be that climate and disaster risk 
information is integrated into urban development and infrastructure planning in Pacific DMCs.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will have three outputs to support the achievement of the TA outcome.  
 
12.  Output 1: Integrated climate and disaster risk assessment tools for planning are 
operational. Output 1 will demonstrate how physical asset and risk information can be adapted 
for local planning purposes and how risk information can be integrated into the development of 
actual plans, policies, and programs to strengthen urban and infrastructure resilience to climate 
and disaster risks. The TA will assess natural disaster and climate change risks using the 
PacRIS and other climate change data and tools. Additionally, it will demonstrate the integration 
of such risk information in at least two urban development plans, resulting in the identification of 
proposed risk mitigation measures in the associated investment plans. Using case studies from 
two Pacific DMCs (to be identified and selected during implementation), a learning-by-doing 
approach will be adopted to develop a methodology for integrating disaster and climate risk 
assessment tools into development planning in Pacific DMCs.6 PacRIS tools may be expanded 
to target and support local risk-sensitive development planning. 
 
13.  Output 2: Integrated tools for mainstreaming disaster and climate risks into urban 
and sector planning are shared. The methodologies and findings from the two case studies 
will be shared with a wide audience of regional stakeholders in a user manual that includes best 
practices and lessons. Output 2 is intended to promote the use of the PacRIS and other climate 
risk data and tools so that disaster risk and climate change considerations form an integral part 
of urban development and infrastructure planning processes in Pacific DMCs. The user manual 
will  be  produced  in  hard  copy  and  shared  with  Pacific  DMC  government  agencies, 
nongovernment organizations, academic institutions, and development partners. An electronic 
version of the manual will also be available for download from the ADB and SPC websites, as 
well as from Pacific Disaster Net, a regional disaster risk management information web portal. 
Urban  and  sector  information  sheets  on  risk-sensitive  development  planning  will  also  be 
produced as part of the TA.  
 
                                                
6  Case study countries will be selected on the basis of (i) the existence of urban development plans, (ii) country 
vulnerability to natural hazards and climate change, and (iii) the availability of detailed climate change and natural 
hazard information for target urban zones.

4 
 
14.  Output 3: Pacific DMC planners apply newly acquired climate and disaster risk 
mainstreaming skills. Output 3 will focus on building capacity and raising awareness among 
Pacific DMC planners responsible for disaster risk management and climate change adaptation 
on the importance of natural disaster and climate sensitive development informed by tools 
developed under the TA. These planners include central and line agencies such as national 
planning and finance ministries, disaster management offices, urban planning agencies, utilities, 
nongovernment  organizations,  private  sector  representatives,  and  development  partners. 
Training activities, using the user manual developed under output 2, will be carried out in each 
of the six participating Pacific DMCs,7 with the aim of (i) raising awareness of PCRAFI tools and 
data,  including  their  practical  value  and  the  importance  of  maintaining  and  sharing  this 
information; (ii) building capacity among key Pacific DMC stakeholders to access, manipulate, 
and use PacRIS data to guide urban development and infrastructure planning; and (iii) building 
national ownership of PacRIS products and tools. Women will be encouraged to participate in all 
of the training activities carried out under the TA. A series of awareness building activities will 
also be carried out regionally to make Pacific DMCs not directly targeted under the TA aware of 
PacRIS tools and data and their value for urban development and infrastructure planning. 
 
15.  It is assumed that Pacific DMC policymakers, with sufficient information and capacity, 
will proactively invest in natural disaster and climate change risk reduction. The main risk to the 
TA is that Pacific DMC policymakers do not enforce development controls or policies designed 
to reduce climate and disaster vulnerability. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $650,000 equivalent, which will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The cost estimates and 
financing plan are presented in Appendix 2. The participating Pacific DMC governments will 
provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, remuneration and per diem for 
staff, miscellaneous administration, and support costs and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency. The TA will be implemented over 24 months from 
2 January 2013 to 2 January 2015. The TA will be overseen by the PCRAFI steering committee 
consisting of representatives from ADB, Japan International Cooperation Agency, the SPC, the 
United Nations Human Settlements Programme, and the World Bank. Activities will be carried 
out in coordination with stakeholders such as the Government of Australia’s Department of 
Climate Change and Energy Efficiency, which is undertaking complementary activities in the 
region  as  part  of  its  Pacific–Australia  Climate  Change  Science  and  Adaptation  Planning 
Program. 
 
18.  The TA will finance 33.25 person-months of international and national consulting inputs: 
(i) risk specialist—team leader (international, 7 person-months); (ii) urban planner (international, 
4  person-months);  (iii)  civil  engineer  (international,  1  person-month);  (iv) economist 
(international,  2  person-months);  (v) expert  peer  review  inputs  (international,  1.25 person-
months);  (vi)  disaster  risk  management  training  specialist  (international,  4  person-months); 
(vii) risk mapping specialist (international, 6 person-months); and (viii) two national coordinators 
(national, 4 person-months each). All consulting services will be rendered intermittently. 
 
                                                
7  The six participating DMCs include Fiji, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, and Vanuatu.

5 
19.  The risk specialist (team leader), urban planner, civil engineer, and economist will be 
recruited through a firm using the consultant qualification selection method. The SPC will be 
contracted  as  a  consulting  firm  using  the  single-source  selection  method  to  recruit  the 
international disaster risk management training specialist, international risk mapping specialist, 
and national coordinators in case study countries. The SPC has the regional mandate for the 
provision of technical support and training to Pacific DMCs for disaster risk reduction and 
disaster management and is also the regional custodian of the PacRIS database. The outline 
terms of reference for consultants is in Appendix 3. 
 
20.  Consultant recruitment will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Procurement of equipment will be 
carried out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  All  equipment  will  be  turned  over  to  the  executing  agency  upon  completion  of  TA 
activities.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
21.  Progress will be monitored against intended outcome and output indicators reflected in 
the design and monitoring framework, and will involve preparing TA progress and completion 
reports. Implementation progress will also be discussed and reviewed during regular meetings 
of the PCRAFI steering committee. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Strengthening Disaster and Climate 
Risk Resilience in Urban Development in the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

Appendix 3  9     
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consulting Services Entity  
 
1.  The consultants will ensure that all technical assistance (TA) works and outputs are fully 
compliant with relevant ADB policies and guidelines. The consulting team members will be 
based at the Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC) in Suva, Fiji to enable sufficient access 
to Pacific Risk Information System (PacRIS) data and tools, including existing hazard risk maps 
produced for Pacific  developing member countries (DMCs), and to ensure a high level of 
coordination between the consultant team and (SPC) specialists involved in the implementation 
of TA activities. The team leader will take overall responsibility for ensuring quality outputs are 
produced under the TA according to agreed milestones, and will prepare and submit quarterly 
TA progress reports based on inputs provided from other consultants. The team leader will also 
provide guidance and coordinate the inputs of other consultants.  
 
1.  Inception  
2.  The consultants will liaise with United Nations Human Settlements Programme officials 
to assess urban planning challenges faced by Pacific DMCs and to determine how climate and 
disaster risk information can practicably inform urban planning processes. The consultants will 
also seek input from the United Nations Human Settlements Programme on required disaster 
and climate risk capacity building needs for Pacific DMC urban planners. The consultants will 
also meet with sector experts to identify the needs of sector users when considering disaster 
and climate risks as part of sector planning and infrastructure design processes.   
 
3.  The  consultants  will  meet  with  officials  from  the  Australian  Department  of  Climate 
Change and Energy Efficiency to discuss how climate change models and tools, such as the 
Pacific Climate Futures tool developed as part of the Pacific–Australia Climate Change Science 
and Adaptation Planning Program, can be integrated with existing PacRIS tools and data to 
assess climate risks to urban and sector investments for selected Pacific DMCs. 
 
4.  Based on discussions with stakeholders and a review of existing data and climate and 
disaster  risk  screening  tools  and  approaches,  the  consultants  will  develop  a  preliminary 
methodology for the two selected Pacific DMC case studies and will propose which two Pacific 
DMCs to use as case studies. The draft methodology and country selection will be discussed 
and endorsed by SPC other regional stakeholders, and the governments of the two selected 
Pacific DMCs. 
 
5.  The team leader will also prepare a draft outline for the training manual, which will 
provide guidance to Pacific DMC urban and sector planners and other stakeholders on how to 
assess disaster and climate change risks and how to integrate them into development planning 
processes.  The  training  manual  will  be  developed  with  inputs  from  SPC’s  disaster  risk 
management training specialist. 
 
6.  A draft inception report will be prepared that outlines the detailed work plan of the 
consulting team (including SPC specialists), including the case studies timeline and approach, 
the training manual preparation, and capacity building and awareness activities delivery. The 
report will be submitted at the end of the first month for consideration by the TA steering 
committee and will be updated based on feedback.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
2.  Integrated Urban/Sector Development Planning  
7.  Stocktaking  of  existing  urban  and  sector  development  policies,  plans  and 
regulations, and associated institutions. The consultants will meet with government agencies 
involved in urban and sector infrastructure and services planning and development, disaster 
management, and climate change. The consultants will take stock of existing urban and sector 
planning documents, including investment master plans and land use plans, and will review 
existing  zoning  regulations,  building  controls,  design  standards,  and  environmental  impact 
assessment requirements. National and sector climate change policies will also be reviewed, 
and  the  extent  to  which  disaster  and  climate  change  priorities  are  reflected  in  planning 
documents will also be evaluated. The consultants will also assess institutional capacities of 
relevant authorities to implement urban and sector plans, screen investments, and enforce 
development controls. An institutional assessment will also examine the roles of national, local, 
and urban and sector agencies, and coordination between agencies. 
 
8.  Strategic site analysis for urban planning. The consultants will determine the area 
covered by urban development plans based on administrative boundaries and will carry out a 
strategic site analysis to identify existing urban land uses, both legal and illegal (e.g., major 
infrastructure, such as roads and utility works, and informal settlements). The consultants will 
also take into account any new major developments that have not yet been included in the 
PacRIS asset database. 
 
9.  Strategic analysis of key sector infrastructure and services. The consultants will 
carry out an assessment of key sector infrastructure and services, taking into account any new 
major sector infrastructure investments that have not yet been included in the PacRIS asset 
database. 
 
10.  Disaster and climate risk mapping and assessment. Using PacRIS data, models and 
risk maps, and existing climate risk information, the consultants will to assess climate and 
disaster risks by mapping natural disaster events and climate change scenarios according to 
probabilities of occurrence. The consultants will use scenario-based planning to examine a 
discrete set of disaster and climate scenarios that are most relevant for local urban and sector 
development  planning  in  the  case  study  countries.  Disaster  and  climate  impacts  will  be 
assessed over time in selected urban areas and sectors, including the risks associated with 
specific land uses and assets in various locations. High risk areas, anticipated changes in 
impacts  over time  resulting from climate  change,  projected  population growth,  and  human 
settlement and economic development patterns will all be identified. Known uncertainties in the 
models and how these should be reflected in the development of recommendations for updating 
urban and sector policies, plans, and regulations will also be identified. 
 
11.  Development  framework.  In  consultation  with  stakeholders,  acceptable  levels  of 
disaster and climate risk will be established to guide policies, standards, and development 
priorities. Based on identified risks, recommendations will be provided on how urban and sector 
planning processes and plans can be strengthened to reflect these risks, including (i) types of 
development that should take place within various urban zones, including appropriate locations 
for specific land uses; (ii) proposed requirements for disaster and climate risk assessment for all 
new developments; (iii) minimum design standards for permitted development within designated 
zones; and (iv) proposed retrofitting measures for key infrastructure that is assessed as being 
highly  vulnerable  to  climate  and  disaster  risks.  Based  on  these  recommendations,  the 
consultants will propose modifications to existing urban development policies, land use plans 
and  associated  zoning  regulations,  building  codes,  and  infrastructure  design  standards,

Appendix 3  11 
including  how  proposed  measures  should  be  prioritized.  The  consultants  will  also  identify 
obstacles which may impede the strengthening of planning processes, such as customary 
ownership of land located in urban areas. 
 
12.  Identification  of  disaster  and  climate-proofing  measures  for  selected  planned 
sector infrastructure investment. Based on climate and disaster risk assessments and levels 
of  acceptable  risk,  the  consultants  will  develop  possible  disaster  and  climate  resilience 
strengthening  measures  to  be  considered  in  feasibility  studies  for  the  planned  sector 
infrastructure  investments.  These  measures  include  the  siting  of  infrastructure  and  the 
incorporation  of  climate-proofing  measures  into  infrastructure  engineering  designs  and 
maintenance requirements to promote the sustainability of sector investments. 
 
13.  Economic analysis of proposed measures to build disaster and climate change 
resilience. An economic analysis of proposed measures to build resilience to natural disaster 
and climate change-related events will be conducted. The economic analysis  will examine 
priority disaster risk reduction and climate change adaptation measures for urban planning, 
sector development, and infrastructure investments proposed in the two case study countries. 
Using the PacRIS and existing climate change data, the economist will compare ―with disaster 
risk reduction and climate change adaptation‖ and ―without disaster risk reduction and climate 
change adaptation‖ situations to estimate the benefits of proposed interventions. The economist, 
in consultation with other consultant team members, will also estimate the proposed costs of 
various disaster risk reduction and climate change adaptation investments. Where costs and 
benefits associated with investments can be estimated with relative certainty and quantified in 
monetary terms, the economic internal rate of return will be calculated. A sensitivity analysis will 
also be carried out to test the robustness of the results of the economic analysis. Proposed 
disaster  risk  reduction  and  climate  change  adaptation  measures  will  be  prioritized,  where 
feasible, based on the results of the economic analysis.  
 
14.  Presentation of findings to stakeholders. The consultants will present draft findings, 
including results of the climate and disaster risk assessments and recommendations, to in-
country  stakeholders,  government  and  nongovernment  representatives,  and  development 
partners.  Based  on  the  feedback  received  during  consultations,  recommendations  will  be 
revised and expanded on, as needed. 
 
3.  Development of Disaster and Climate Risk Screening Training Manual 
15.  Based on pilot testing as part of selected Pacific DMC case studies, the proposed 
methodology for integrating disaster and climate risks into urban and sector planning processes 
and investment projects will be updated, taking into consideration specific Pacific DMC contexts 
such as data quality, institutional capacity, and regulatory environments. 
 
16.  Case study summaries will be included in the training manual containing best practices 
and lessons in the development of country case studies. 
 
4.  Awareness and Training Activities 
17.  Following the completion of country case studies, SPC will organize a training activity in 
each of the six participating countries to (i) build national capacity to access the PacRIS and 
existing climate change data; (ii) apply risk information to planning processes; and (iii) share the 
findings from the case studies. The national training activities will target a wide range of country 
policy  makers,  including  representatives  from  central  and  line  agencies,  urban  and  local

councils, utilities, nongovernment organizations, the private sector, and development partners. 
The consultants will provide assistance with the design and delivery of training activities. 
 
18.  The consultants will participate in selected regional climate and disaster events to raise 
awareness among a wide range of Pacific DMC policymakers, nongovernment representatives, 
and development partners on the existence and practical use of PacRIS data and tools, and 
how these can be used to support disaster and climate resilient development planning.  
 
19.  A total of four international consultants over a 24-month period are required for a total of 
14  person-months  of  input,  to  be  recruited  through  a  consulting  firm.  The  international 
consultants will include (i) a risk specialist—team leader (7 person-months, intermittent); (ii) an 
urban planner (4 person-months, intermittent); (iii) a civil engineer (1person-month, intermittent); 
and (iv) an economist (2. person-months, intermittent). 
 
B.  Secretariat of the Pacific Community  
 
20.  Two international and two national consultants will be engaged over a 24-month period, 
for a total of 18 person-months of input from SPC.  
 
21.  Disaster  risk  management  training  specialist  (international,  4  person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist will work with the risk specialist (team leader) in the design and 
delivery of capacity building activities. The specialist will develop training activities under the TA 
that address identified capacity gaps among urban and sector planners in Pacific DMCs. SPC 
will organize training activities in each of the six participating DMC countries. 
 
22.  The specialist will prepare a draft training plan, to be included in the draft inception 
report, for capacity building activities carried out as part of the TA. The design of the training 
activities will draw on best practices and lessons from SPC’s experiences in building capacity in 
the region. The training schedule, where feasible, will be coordinated with related training 
activities delivered by SPC and other development partners in the six participating countries. 
 
23.  The specialist will provide input into the development of the training manual developed 
under the TA and ensure that it is written in a clear manner and style appropriate for Pacific 
DMC urban and sector planners.  
   
24.  Following the development of country case studies and the draft training manual, the 
specialist  will  be  work  with  the  team  leader  to  organize  a  training  activity  in  each  of  the 
participating  countries,  build  national  capacity  to  access  the  PacRIS  and  existing  climate 
change  data,  and  apply  risk  information  to  planning  processes.  The  results  and 
recommendations  of  the  draft  case  studies  will  be  presented  to  participants.  The  national 
training will target a wide range of country policy makers involved in development planning, 
including representatives from central and line agencies, urban and local councils, utilities, 
nongovernment organizations, and the private sector.  
 
25.  The specialist will participate in selected regional climate and disaster events to raise 
awareness among a wide range of Pacific DMC policymakers, nongovernment representatives, 
and development partners on the existence and practical use of PacRIS data and tools and how 
these can be used to support improved development planning.  
 
26.  Risk mapping specialist (international, 6 person-months, intermittent). The specialist 
will facilitate the team leader’s access to the PacRIS data platform and other data housed at

SPC and will provide input into the development of a methodology for using risk information to 
incorporate  climate  and  disaster  resilience  into  development  planning for  the  two  selected 
Pacific DMC case studies. 
 
27.  To assess climate and natural disaster risks for the selected case studies, the specialist 
will  produce  scenario-based  risk  maps  for  the  selected  urban  and  geographic  areas  that 
illustrate assets as areas at risk from natural disasters of various magnitudes. These risk maps 
will also project climate change impacts based on available risk information contained in the 
PacRIS, existing climate change models, and other data sources.  
 
28.  National coordinators (two persons, national, 4 person-months each, intermittent). The 
coordinators will provide logistical and coordination support for consultant team members. The 
coordinators should have strong in-country networks in the disaster management and/or urban 
and  sector  planning  communities  to  be  able  to  facilitate  meetings  with  government  and 
nongovernment officials. The coordinators will also provide any logistical support required to 
carry out case studies, including making arrangements for fieldwork. The coordinators will assist 
with  organizing  all  in-country  capacity  building  and  training  activities  and  stakeholder 
consultations. 
 
C.  Peer Review  
 
29.  Expert peer review inputs (international, 1.25 person-months, intermittent). The peer 
review team will consist of recognized experts in the field of disaster and climate resilient 
development planning. The experts will review draft outputs produced under the TA to ensure 
that they meet required quality standards. The objective of the peer review is to provide an in-
depth  assessment  of  the  assumptions,  calculations,  extrapolations,  methodology,  and 
conclusions  pertaining  to  the  climate  and  disaster  risk  and  vulnerability  assessments. 
Additionally, the review should assess proposed measures to build resilience against identified 
risks in urban, sector, and infrastructure planning and projects in Pacific DMCs. It is intended to 
identify any errors or omissions that might affect the credibility of the work carried out in case 
study countries under the TA, which is intended as a model that will be scaled up and replicated 
across the region. As part of the peer review, it is expected that a documented review of the 
work will be completed following the completion of the draft case studies and draft training 
manual to demonstrate to  stakeholders that activities  meet the specific needs of intended 
beneficiaries and are technically adequate, competently performed, and properly documented.
